Award.AwardTitle: Elastic Layered Metal-Organic Frameworks for Carbon Capture

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project examines the feasibility of using new solid sorbents for CO2 capture from flue gas streams. The research is a combination of molecular modeling and experimentation to study the interactions between CO2 and Elastic Layered Metal-Organic Frameworks (ELMs). The project also includes an LCA for a hypothetical 500 MW power plant retrofitted with an ELM adsorption system. The hypothesis is that such absorbents would be highly efficient in adsorbing and releasing CO2 without substantial energy penalties. The project addresses head-on the challenge of CO2 capture in the context of messy flue gas streams, which contain H2O and other impurities such as SO2, NOx, etc. Repeated cycling of exposure to a moist gas stream may ultimately degrade these sorbents. Molecular modeling of this process will provide an indication of the extent to which this technology is feasible. If successful, the advances would have the potential to be transformative in guiding the design of effective CO2 solid sorbent structures and economics of carbon capture. Research findings will be integrated into distance education classes taught to industrial audiences and outreach to middle and high school students in Ann Arbor. Undergraduates will participate in the research. A collaboration with researchers in Japan is an important component of the project.
This project is co-funded by OISE-Japan.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, molecular simulation and adsorption experiments were carried out in tandem to investigate use of novel elastic layered metal-organic framework (ELM) adsorbents (Figure 1) for CO2 capture from combustion gas mixtures at high CO2 sorption capacity and high selectivity over a broad range of flue gas conditions, at modest heats of adsorption, and with ease of regeneration and full CO2 capture and release over narrow ranges of temperature or pressure. In concert with experimental studies for carbon dioxide adsorption at supercritical temperatures (Figure 2), molecular modeling was used to evaluate the selectivity of ELM adsorbents for CO2 adsorption from gas mixtures (Figure 3) and the durability of ELM adsorbents under realistic combustion gas conditions.

Research was performed on the following: (1) Hydrothermal cycling and sorption experiments to determine steam stability and CO2 capture for ELM sorbents in moist environments. (2) CO2 adsorption simulations (Figure 4) on ELMs from pre- and post-combustion gas mixtures to determine the effect of ELM metal ion and framework composition on CO2 sorption selectivity, sorption capacity, and sorption enthalpy. (3) Evaluation of the stability of ELMs to binding of trace stack gas acid oxides (CO, NO2, SO2) using density functional theory methods. (4) Life cycle analysis for a coal-burning plant retrofitted for CO2 separation to quantify the sustainability benefits of CO2 capture in a scaled ELM-11 adsorption system, relative to conventional CO2 scrubbing using amine absorption. Five submitted publications and ten conference presentations have resulted from this ongoing project. Two graduate students, one postdoctoral student, and five undergraduate students were sponsored as research assistants.

The activities had significant intellectual merit in the development of improved materials and property knowledge for combustion gas carbon capture under conditions of elevated temperature and moisture content. New simulation codes were developed in the course of the research and are available for use by other researchers in this area.

Broader impacts of the activities included an international collaboration with scientists at two Japanese universities; employment of members of underrepresented groups as lab assistants; outreach to area elementary schools through the Washtenaw County Science Olympiad; and incorporation of research findings into distance courses on energy infrastructure systems.
